Dear Ms. Olik:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff to Resident Ratio
Title
Rule Code & (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Section supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
Description checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Two youth were in a common room together and when staff were
not looking, one youth rubbed the other youth's leg and tried to
have sexual intercourse. Youth resisted.
Investigation Interviews:
A message was left for Complainant on June 24, 2024,
detailing the allegations and asking if they had additional
information. A return message was received on June 26, 2024,
and Complainant reported they had no additional information
outside of the detailed allegations.
Assistant Manager was interviewed face-to-face on June 25,
2024. Assistant Manager reviewed video footage with DCWL
Consultant and pointed out the amount of time Youth A, Youth B
and two other youth were left unsupervised in the conference
2

room. Assistant Manager said she does all the training for the
facility and trained Staff 1 to keep eyes on the youth, have them
move with her throughout the house as needed. For example, if
she needed to make dinner have them either help in the kitchen or
sit at the dining room table in her line of sight. Assistant Manager
said Staff 1 violated the policy and procedures of the facility by
leaving the youth unattended for almost four hours, and only
checked on them about three times. Assistant Manager said Staff
1 was immediately suspended pending investigation of these
allegations.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on July 9, 2024. Youth
A said she was previously placed at Isabella County Non-Secure
Detention approximately a month ago. Youth A said she was
placed with Youth B, and they started out being “friends”. Youth A
said during her placement she was left unsupervised by Staff 1
“whenever she worked”. Youth A said Staff 1 would be on her cell
phone and allow the youth in different rooms of the facility without
her being present or supervising. Youth A said there was a day
when she, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D were allowed in the
conference room for many hours and Staff 1 was not supervising
them. Youth A said during that time she was sitting at the table
next to Youth B and he put his hand over her clothing on her thigh
and said he loved her. Youth A said she told Youth B “you don’t
even know me” but he did not seem to care. Youth A said Youth B
then began to move his hand up her thigh towards her vagina and
she told him to stop but he wouldn’t. Youth A said she took her
hand and tried to move his hand, but he would not stop so she got
up and started to yell at him. Youth A said Youth B became really
angry and called her a “ho” several times. Youth A said Youth C
and Youth D were also in the room however they did not see
Youth B with his hand on her thigh but did hear her yelling at him
afterwards. Youth A said Staff 1 heard her “cussing” Youth B out
and told Youth A she needed to stop talking to Youth B. Youth A
denied Youth B doing any other sexual acts or advances. Youth A
said she wrote about the incident in her journal and Assistant
Manager reviewed the journal and saw what she had written and
immediately addressed the incident with her and Youth B. Youth A
said after Assistant Manager found out about the incident Staff 1
did not work again and she was no longer allowed to be alone with
Youth B. Youth A said the other staff that worked at the facility
never allowed the youth to be unsupervised in other rooms of the
house.
Youth B’s mother was called on July 11, 2024. Youth B’s
mother reported Youth B was staying with his father and confirmed
3

his phone number. Youth B’s father was called on July 15, 2024,
and July 18, 2024, and the phone number is disconnected. Youth
B was not interviewed.
Youth C was interviewed via telephone on July 15, 2024. Youth
C reported that she was at Isabella Non-Secure Detention Center
from June 8, 2024, until June 17, 2024. Youth C said there was
usually one staff working in the facility at a time. Youth C said all of
the staff would either be in the room with the youth or check on
them every five minutes or less except for Staff 1. Youth C said
Staff 1 allowed youth to be in other areas of the house or outside
and would check on them “once and a while”. Youth C said there
was a day Staff 1 was working and allowed youth to be
unsupervised for “a long time” in the conference room. Youth C
said during that time Youth B tried to get Youth A “to do
inappropriate sexual things” with him however she refused. Youth
C said Youth B put his hand on Youth A’s thigh and moved it up
toward her crotch area and Youth A had to move Youth B’s hand
off her. Youth C said Staff 1 was not supervising when this
occurred. Youth C said the other staff found out when they read
Youth A’s journal. Youth C said she did not have anything like this
happen to her and she felt safe while at the facility. Youth C said
she argued with Youth B often and staff always intervened and
separated the youth.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on July 15, 2024. Youth
D said he was placed at Isabella Non-Secure Detention Center
with Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C. Youth D said sometimes two
staff would be working but mainly it was one staff at the facility
with the youth. Youth D said the youth were only allowed to be
outside if two staff were working. Youth D said all staff except Staff
1 would make the youth be in the same room as them during
waking hours. Youth D said Staff 1 would allow the youth to “chill”
alone while she was on her phone in the other rooms and would
come check on them. Youth D said there was a day when Staff 1
allowed him, Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C to be in the
conference room for “a while” and she was in the dining room.
Youth D said during that time Youth B tried to “cuddle up” on Youth
A and was rubbing her thigh over her clothing for about fifteen
minutes. Youth D said Staff 1 did not see this occur as she was
not in the room and none of the youth told Staff 1 about the
incident. Youth D said Youth A did not want Youth B to rub her
thigh and made him stop. Youth D said he never had anything
happen to him while at the facility and he felt safe there.
4

Staff 1 was attempted to be interviewed via telephone on July
16, 2024, and July 25, 2024. Staff 1 is no longer an employee of
Isabella Non-Secure Detention Center. Staff 1 did not answer her
phone or return the phone call, and therefore was not interviewed.
Video Review:
Video footage of June 16, 2024, conference room was reviewed
on June 25, 2024. The video footage shows four youth in the
conference room from 15:57 until about 22:00. Staff 1 is
positioned on a second camera in the dining room/school area at
a desk for most of the time. Staff 1 only checks on the youth three
times during the duration of the time they were in the conference
room. The youth in the conference room move in and out of the
room at times. They throw playing cards, books, and games.
Youth A and Youth B sit by each other several times throughout
the video on the same side of the table. Youth A and Youth B’s
hands move about and are on the table and then under the table.
There is no video footage that shows Youth B touching Youth A.
There is no video footage of Youth B and Youth A having sex or
attempting to remove clothing to have sex.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 1 personnel file: Staff 1 had discipline on May 17,
2024, and May 21, 2024, for not following the facility call-in
procedure, and on June 18, 2024, for lack of supervision as
it pertained to this investigation. Staff 1 participated in
training on February 17, 2024, for all facility policies and
procedures including the supervision and “keeping youth in
eyesight”.
• McBride Quality Care Services Employee Policies
Handbook was reviewed. The handbook outlines the
expectation for Telephones and states “Employees are
prohibited from carrying personal cellular phone or other
electronic devices for the purposes of receiving or initiating
personal phone calls or digital communication while on
duty. Texting is also prohibited while on duty.”
• Isabella Non-Secure Detention Home Policy and
Procedures was reviewed. The policy specifically states,
“Principles of Youth Supervision; Unless participating in an
activity approved by administration, youth are never to be
out of the visual contact of staff. Note: SUPERVISION IS
THE TOP PRIORITY OF STAFF.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per video review and
youth interviews, Staff 1 did not check on the youth in varying
intervals not to exceed 15 minutes nor follow the agency policy
regarding youth supervision and use of personal cellphone. The
5

agency policies clearly indicate that youth are never to be out of
sight of staff and that staff are not allowed to use personal
cellphones while working. Youth reported and were seen for long
periods of time unsupervised in the conference room while Staff 1
is sitting at a desk on her cellphone.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
Special Investigation dated 1/20/23, CAP approval dated 2/9/23
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
